text: How do I apply a global theme override so it affects Mantine components across my app?
atoms_required: Wrap your app/root with MantineProvider (root-level usage).
Pass a theme override via the MantineProvider theme prop (MantineProvider theme={...}).
Define a theme override object (e.g., createTheme({...}) or an inline MantineThemeOverride object).

text: How can I set a global default border radius so most components use it automatically?
atoms_required: Set defaultRadius in the theme override (defaultRadius: ...).
Apply the override globally via MantineProvider theme={...}.
Indicate or demonstrate that the defaultRadius affects most components by default (e.g., Button/TextInput example or an explicit statement).

text: How can I define and use a new Button style variant via theming?
atoms_required: Use the data-variant selector/attribute as the mechanism for the custom variant (e.g., [data-variant='myVariant']).
Wire the styling into the Button via theming (e.g., theme.components.Button with Button.extend and classNames/styles).
Apply the theme through MantineProvider theme={theme} so it’s available app-wide.
Demonstrate usage with <Button variant='...'> so the variant is actually selected.

text: How can I add a persistent top header area as part of the main application layout?
atoms_required: Use AppShell as the layout container.
Configure and render a header area (e.g., header={{ height: ... }} and/or <AppShell.Header>...</AppShell.Header>).
Mention that AppShell uses fixed positioning / header stays persistent (does not scroll with the page).
Include the main content area (e.g., <AppShell.Main>...</AppShell.Main>) to complete the layout pattern.

text: How can I attach a custom validation rule to a single field using Mantine useForm?
atoms_required: Configure validation in useForm for the specific field (e.g., validate: { field: (value) => ... } or validate(values) returning an error for that field).
The validator returns an error message (or ReactNode) when invalid and null/omits when valid.
Show the field is actually bound to the form (e.g., getInputProps('field') / equivalent binding on the input).

text: How can I validate that two fields match in Mantine useForm while showing the error only on the second field?
atoms_required: Attach validation to the second field only (e.g., confirmPassword) so the error appears only there.
Compare the second field against the first field’s value (e.g., (value, values) => value !== values.password ... or matchesField('password', ...)).
Use Mantine useForm validation configuration (validate rules object or validator helper) in a runnable pattern.

text: How can I target and override specific internal elements of a Mantine component using the Styles API with classNames?
atoms_required: Identify the correct Styles API selector(s) for the component’s internal element(s) you want to target (selector names).
Pass a classNames object mapping selector -> CSS class name(s) to the component instance (classNames={{ selector: '...' }}).
Provide the CSS class definitions (e.g., via CSS Modules or regular CSS) that implement the override for those internal elements.

text: How do I set up MantineProvider in Next.js App Router (app/layout.tsx)?
atoms_required: Place the setup in the App Router root layout file (app/layout.tsx) so it applies globally.
Import Mantine core styles at the root (import '@mantine/core/styles.css').
Wrap the application with <MantineProvider>{children}</MantineProvider> in the layout body.
Add <ColorSchemeScript /> inside <head> in the root layout.
Spread mantineHtmlProps onto the <html> element (e.g., <html {...mantineHtmlProps}>...) to avoid hydration warnings.

text: In Mantine, which styling approach is most performant at runtime, and why?
atoms_required: Identify CSS Modules as the most performant styling approach (in Mantine context).
State the key reason: CSS Modules generate static CSS that is not re-evaluated at runtime.
Include Mantine-specific justification/recommendation (e.g., most Mantine component styles use CSS Modules / recommended to use CSS Modules in most cases).

text: How do I render a stacked BarChart in Mantine Charts with multiple data series?
atoms_required: Use the BarChart component from @mantine/charts (render <BarChart ... />).
Provide chart data via the data prop (array of objects).
Set dataKey to the field used for the x-axis categories (e.g., dataKey='month').
Define multiple series via the series prop, with each series name matching keys in the data objects (optionally specifying color).
Enable stacking by setting type='stacked' on BarChart.

text: Does Mantine provide a built-in way to synchronize state across browser tabs (e.g., theme/color scheme), and how do I use it?
atoms_required: Use the useLocalStorage hook from @mantine/hooks (import and call it).
Configure it with a localStorage key and a defaultValue via the options object (e.g., { key: '...', defaultValue: ... }).
State that useLocalStorage syncs state across opened tabs by subscribing to the storage event (i.e., updates propagate between tabs).
Mention or show the sync option (sync: true, which is enabled by default) that controls cross-tab synchronization.
